awd_titl_txt: Bulk rheology of fault damage zone materials and its implication for interseismic fault mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to better understand the tectonic loading process leading to devastating earthquakes in major plate boundaries. Advances in the past decade allows scientists to capture and simulate first-order characteristics of the earthquake cycle, but challenges remain in understanding the randomness and spatial variability of earthquake phenomena. This project specifically focuses on one of the complexities that may arise due to the fact that faults may not only slip at the very fault plane itself, but the surrounding damaged rock can also deform to accommodate plate motion. The project, carried out in collaboration with researchers from National Central University, Taiwan, involves characterization of damage zone samples from the Chelungpu fault, Taiwan, coupled with deformation experiments on those samples to explore the behavior of the damage zone under stress. Better understanding of such phenomena will illuminate what is still lacking in current earthquake fault models and lead to improved accuracy of seismic hazard analyses. The project would also advance desired societal outcomes through a strong research collaboration with Taiwanese scientists plus the opportunity for graduate students to exchange scientific ideas and cultural experiences essential to foster future generation of scientists who will work in an international collaborative environment.

The objective of this study is to characterize the ductile deformational properties of fault damage zone rocks and to evaluate the importance of such behavior on fault mechanics. Most analytical and numerical fault mechanics models treat faults as a frictional interface embedded between elastic host rocks and does not take into account the peculiar characteristics of the damage zone surrounding the fault plane. However, damage zone rocks may undergo time-dependent ductile deformation even under crustal conditions, which has significant consequences on how shear stress develops on a fault during the interseismic period. The project focuses on the Chelungpu fault, Taiwan, where the high-quality core material was recovered from the 2004 International Continental Drilling Project. Detailed description of the fault damage zones in the Chelungpu fault system will be made with emphasis on fracture density, followed by creep experiments using damage zone samples to measure time-dependent strain behavior. Using lab-derived constitutive equations, deformation behavior of the damage zone under tectonic conditions will be evaluated. The ductile constitutive law will be combined with fault frictional properties in a numerical model to quantify the relative contribution of each domains, damage zone and fault core, to the total fault deformation during interseismic tectonic loading. Many geophysical observations suggest that permanent off-fault deformation may be occurring over long time scales (greater than a year). If, for instance, the partial-coupling of subduction interfaces inferred from geodetic studies is indeed due to steady off-fault deformation, the study may impact understanding of the stress accumulation process during interseismic tectonic loading.

por.por_cntn:
[Overview]

The objective of this study was to characterize the ductile deformational properties of fault damage zone rocks and to evaluate the importance of such behavior on fault mechanics. We choose the Chelungpu fault, Taiwan, as our study area for the high-quality drilled-core material and log data that exists from the Taiwan Chelungpu-fault Drilling Project (TCDP) in 2004. Some difficulties were encountered due to disagreement with past studies, fragile nature of natural fault damage zone samples, and interruption of laboratory activities due to the pandemic. Therefore, additional time was spent reanalyzing the log data from TCDP and producing synthetic damage zone rocks from TCDP drilled cores.

[Outcome - Intellectual Merit]

We re-examined borehole image logs from TCDP in detail, which revealed that the inconsistency between past studies on the in-situ stress state near the Chelungpu fault was mainly caused by the lithological variation along the TCDP borehole. Results also revealed that the stress state is closer to an isotropic stress state within the fault damage zone of the Chelungpu fault, which we hypothesize to be the result of (differential) stress-relaxation caused by the ductile deformation of the damage zone rocks. The findings were published in the Journal of Geophysical Research (Talukdar et al., 2022).

Sedimentary host rock cores above the Chelungpu fault were impacted in a Split Hopkinson Pressure Bar apparatus in Ohio State University to produce synthetic damage zone rocks with varying degree of damage. The damaged rocks tested in a conventional triaxial apparatus in University of Wisconsin-Madison showed that damaged sedimentary rocks do exhibit ductile creep deformational behavior, especially with increasing damage, even under dry conditions and room-temperature conditions. A published viscoplasticity law by Haghighat et al. (2020) was fitted against the data successfully to show that the viscous behavior can be best described using a Perzyna viscoplasticity law which acknowledges the stiffening (increase in viscosity) as the rock accumulates plastic strain (pore volume loss due to compaction). We also observed ultrasonic velocity increase by few % during creep compaction, which is comparable to the magnitude of postseismic seismic velocity recovery observed in fault zones after major earthquakes. Results are in preparation for publication.

[Outcome - Broader Impact]

The confirmation that damaged rocks exhibit ductile behavior suggest the possibility of stress relaxation that takes place in a slow manner between earthquakes around fault zones. If true, such effect must be incorporated in future modeling studies that simulate earthquake cycles because stress relaxation significantly impact how the driving force of earthquakes build up between earthquakes. We could not complete a numerical modeling study under this project, but future efforts will focus on how to incorporate viscoplastic laws in models that account for realistic fault damage zone geometries.

The project supported the training of a graduate student who gained multiple laboratory/analytical research skills and international/domestic collaboration experiences.

Modified by: Hiroki Sone
